text: how do I list the files in a package?
try dpkg -L <packagename>
assuming it's installed
then I think you would need apt-file
heh - thoreauputic
I guess your client is highlighting the line
change your irssi theme so you can read things ;)
I'm stuck with it now since that is how I'm known
seriously, change your irssi theme ;)
you might need to read someone's long or short <yellow-dude>
hrm - lots of docs on irssi.org
some say gnomebaker, others like graveman
topyli (I think) suggested ` sudo chmod -x /usr/bin/esd`
I've done it and it seems to be working well here :)

(I can see your name now that I've changed the background to black and the foreground to white) I think I still need esd for some programs (like totem?) - but according to that RestrictedFormats wiki page, you can ask esd to back off when it's not active
hmm - I use totem-xine
works fine that way
also I used the suggestions for fixing sound on http://ubuntuguide.org
thanks.  i hadn't heard of that site before.  looks good!
yes, it's a one - stop shop, pretty much :)
I don't agree with all of it , but it seems pretty sound in general
how did you install the 686 kernel?  I don't see a package in synaptic for it
it's there: apt-cache search linux-image
heh.  'linux-image', not 'kernel-2.6.something-686'?  odd that the kernel doesn't have 'kernel' in its package name, wouldn't you say?
well, linux is the kernel - the rest is the OS ( talk to Richard Stallman *grin*)
I know, and that's fair enough.
GNU/BSD/Ubuntu/Debian Linux *smile*
does fuser /dev/snd/*   show the devices in use?
do you mean 'fuser -c'?
the command you told me doesn't print any output.
but if I use the '-c' flag I see a lot of output
oh, I see...  -c means to show all processes using all files on the same device as those devices...
if I play some music, then your fuser command shows that the mplayer is using /dev/snd/pcmC0D0p and /dev/snd/timer
and if I stop the music player, fuser shows that nothing is using the devices
you can play sound then?
I can play sounds, but I can't hear them...
that's logical, is it not?
it's as if my ears stopped working.  ubuntu tells me they're playing.
hmm... I find killing everything sound related and restarting alsa sometimes resurrects sound
without alsa you won'r hear a thing
maybe I need to run alsa then...  what's the command?
all the other bits like OSS need alsa as well in 2.6.* kernels
I see 'shutting down ALSA - ok; setting up ALSA - ok' - but still 'ps -ef | grep -i alsa' shows nothing, and still my ears tell me that nothing's playing
alsa won't show up like that on your ps command
I'm playing music here and alsa doesn't figure in that output
run alsamixer and use m
do what bob2 and I suggested
hahah
you have a new weapon in your arsenal :)
I never saw 'alsamixer' before, in all my Mandrake/Mandriva/CentOS days
it's well hidden ;)
like a lot of other utilities, you only find them by living in the cli for a while
it's funny you mentioned 'Your Arsenal'.  It's the name of a Morrissey CD.  The track I was using to test the sound, in fact the only .mp3 I have on this computer was a Morrissey track.
I'm psychic, evidently ;-)
people's mileage seems to vary a lot with media players, I've noticed
why?
versioning problems, broken updates etc
much grief for many when they upgraded to Hoary
I never tried it, was interested to hear why you don't recommend it.  thanks.
what *would* you recommend as a temporary source to get, say, win32 codecs?
I used marillat testing - but I commented it out right away after I got the codecs
I think they should live in /usr/lib/win32 as Fator_Dee says
oh, ok
that worked - I made a new directory /usr/lib/win32 and moved them all in there
aha ! :D
amongst other things, ...
funny that SiS7012 is on irq 11 _ I think mine is on 18
that's the sound card, right?
yes
do 'cat /proc/interrupts' to see the IRQs
18:    3690083   IO-APIC-level  SiS SI7012
your 'wget http://nick-zap.home.comcast.net/stuff/unix.pdf| xpdf' command has a couple of problems
OK - I just thought it would work: i guess the pipe doesn't
thanks for the correction
you can 'wget -O- http:/...' if you want to write to stdout
but I don't know if xpdf can read a document from a pipe anyway
right click, properties, open with
I can do that, but it doesn't seem to offer me any option to 'always use this app by default in future'
properties, open with , add, check the one you want
I can see 'open with', but not 'add'
'properties' at the bottom - choose the 'open with' tab
I think you are in the wrong dialog
after right click, go to the bottom entry (properties)
ok.  i see.  that seems to have hung nautilus though
hmm - odd
half an hour ago it told me that nautilus had crashed and asked if I wanted to inform the developers.  but then it got better again.
I use rox filer here, mostly (I don't like nautilus much and I'm currently using fluxbox, not gnome)
I've never liked gnome much.  First impressions with ubuntu were that finally it was stable, but it seems not to be the case really.
it's OK - I'm happier with fluxbox or xfce4 personally
sudo apt-get install apt-howto
but it's fairly detailed
I like that.  using 'apt' to learn about apt...  :)
I like details.  It's vagueness I don't like.  :)
heh - 'It's a Family channel' ;)
it tends to choke
I've had better luck with amarok (KDE app, of course, though)
hmm - ideology or experience?
amarok was pretty good - it coped with all my mp3 files
neither.  I've nothing against KDE, but I just think it makes sense not to mix GTK and KDE apps, for the sake of memory conservation
I think amarok is the best I've tried so far - but I often just start up xmms or beep-media-player from a directory or use streamtuner
mono
verb?
um - I meant 'mono not .NET' but I guess you knew that
ok, i see.
otherwise the answer as always is '42' ;-)
hmm... the java trap in action then :/
yes, but...  it's SO pretty...  and SO functional!
heh - install some xmms skins right away!
or winamp skins if that's your thing...
xmms skins work with beep-media-player?
yup
shift-drag
should snap to the edge in gnome
yeah, I wish I could find that info too
I guess it's user, system, nice, idle, then - um - 'wait'?  and as for 'hi' and 'si' I have no idea
yes, the first few seem pretty clear at least
my 'wa' shows zero here
I think mine is usually zero, but I'm running an 'updatedb' with my huge external drive mounted.
hmm... w_   access ? Guessing...
is this warty or hoary? Hoary should give you your country code
this is hoary.  I told it my country when I installed, but it set my up using the .com address...
how should hoary give me my country code?  I'm not sure I follow you.
crimsun is right -  CC.archive.ubuntu.com, where CC is the country code
mine is au so au is prepended
does that make sense?
sorry, I was away, hunting the slivovice
I understand.  but should hoary have put the 'cz.' in for me?  or am I expected to know that I have to put it there?
my understanding is thet it should be put in for you
mine was put in automatically
that's strange then.
hmm - maybe there is no cz sever address, I don't know
what do you see if you run 'grep hoary-security /etc/apt/sources.list' please?
because: 'unknown host au.security.ubuntu.com'
I get 4 lines
what are the hostnames?
I can paste in #flood if you care to look
as bob2 said, it ends up at  ge-0-0.access8.lon2.mnet.net.uk via the US - funny !
so the au sever is in the UK - what a joke
so I'm going to use ubuntu.cz instead...  that doesn't go via several oceans...
I guess you should pick a source from http://www.ubuntulinux.org/wiki/Archive
what *are* they thinking?
indeed
there's a 'sensor' command I seem to recall
hmm..maybe not
consider doing 'set -o noclobber' in your .bashrc - then you can't accidentally lose stuff by doing '>' instead of '>>'
it's Ok - I didn't clobber anything as it was a test: but good point
next time you might not be so lucky :)
indeed
thanks :)
dist-upgrade
you X link is quite amusing :)
I'm reading it too.  He's quite angry :)
it's an old piece, but still pretty much true today.
you might want to read that URL
ubotu's
thanks, but I think that's the link which got my into this mess in the first place...
oh, sorry - it worked for me fine :/
for a rough estimste cd to /var/cache /apt/archives and try ' for each in *.deb ; do du -h $each ; done '
assuming you haven't cleared your apt cache of course
I was being a bit silly... synaptic allows me to just list installed packages, and to sort by size...  duh!
ah - much easier ! :)
I just did mine and discovered for some reason a lot of debs have been cleared from my cache without my asking: this isn't very Debianish - I expected all to be there! Odd...
I'm sure I saw somewhere that the cache is cleared of anything over 7 days old?
I'll google... but on debian I seem to recall this didn't happen
the apt-get clean command is supposed to clear the cache explicitly, I thought
the main trouble isn't rpm so much as the weird variety of different rms
there's only one rms!
like SUSE and Mandriva are  not compatible with Redhat
sorry typo ;)
yes, but a Mandriva RPM won't necessarily work on SUSE, for example
it would speed up performance if he compiled his own packages, surely?
well, i encourage the use of Ubuntu packages, because I don't want to hold people's hands whem they break their package management
but i guess that's presumptuous of me, so yaeh
there is ntpdate (which is the thing you saw) and an ntpdate daemon (which isn't installed by default)
aah, i see.
no worries:)
you might want to try installing deborphan
might I?
well, deborphan will find orphaned packages :)
ooh, that sounds good.
thanks for suggesting deborphan.  that helped a lot
you're welcome :)
you built a deb for it?
I did.  I ran 'make-kpkg --initrd --revision=cim.2.6.12.1 kernel_image' like the readme told me to.
is it in /var/cache/apt/archives ?
aha
I clean the cache regularly
OK
but you just discovered that the system believed you when you named it kernel-image *grin*
you should suggest this as a way to reduce confusion among new users ;-)
my 6 'virtual consoles' are all black on black too.
ah - not so good
setterm might help...
well, your new kernel is entertaining at least :)
man setterm *evil grin*
setterm doesn't seem to have any effect on the VCs
oh. Is your /etc/inittab normal looking?

I have 2 kernels installed - the regular breezy one, and the one I built myself.  One has working VCs, the other doesn't.  So it can't be anything about /etc/inittab, right?  Or vga= options.  Can it?
right to /etc/inittab - vga= can be set per kernel in /boot/grub/menu.lst I think
on the kernel line
I compared the list of modules in /lib/modules for the two kernels.  I found that the one that works has initrd/vesafb.ko and mine doesn't...
then I know not, I fear
aha!
I'm guessing that's the problem.  but how can I get mine to build that?  Mine has 'kernel/drivers/video/vesafb.ko', as does the working one, but the working one also has vesafb.ko in '.../initrd/'
I don't know - you need someone versed in the ways of kernel building
hmmm.  where might I find such a creature?
erm... dare I suggest #debian ?
of course any mention of Ubuntu is deprecated if you try that ;-)
I heard that way be dragons.
well, there be some clever dragons there
I'll be sure to take some gold coins with me and an offering.
I suggest sacrificing a goat at the full moon before proceeding
never tried it - why would you want to do that?
curiosity
I assume apt/dpkg is clever enough to warn you if you are about to commit sepuku
what does the colon do in front of the 'exit 0' in that script?
I don't know :)
it does nothing apparently
how did you establish that? (curious)
'man bash' (evil grin)
aha! hehehe
is '' a glottal stop?
I don't know.  I copy/pasted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ubuntu
ah OK :)
heh - the wiki page for ubuntu pronunciation starts to read like a slashdot comments page ;) Some people have no idea...
I meant wikipedia of course
'The wikipedia entry for 'python' should point at the programming language <--- how brain-dead can people be?
is that the same team that typed the works of Shakespeare ?
they're not THAT old!
it's quite possible to have been running an FTP server for years, but to be a linux noob.  windows has ftp servers too you know...
I did say 'probably' :)
point taken though ;)
yup
maybe it's a breezy thang?
Oh I see - you found it in breezy?
woah!
(I'm kindof cheating - that count includes all the KDE dependancies)

either.  I need to find libgtk2.0-0 version 2.8.4-0ubuntu1
(with source too, if possible)
looked in /var/cache/apt/archives ? (I mean if you already have it)
unfortunately only version 2.8.4-0ubuntu2 is in there
is there no archive online?
I would assume there is - have you tried packages.ubuntu.com ?
that's an idea
it seems that packages.u.c only has the current version for each of the beasts
do you have it in your /var/cache/apt/archives?
hang on
sorry - no luck
the originators might be interested in your patch :)
yes, but ssh -X works fine
it's always possiblr you actually *needed* the dependencies ;P
I don't need them - I've compiled much more recent versions of them from the CVS repository
aha I see :)
did you install them with checkinstall? I guess apt doesn't know about them?
the problem is that GNU Emacs is constantly in development, but never makes a release.  the ubuntu version is very out of date, but it's the newest release.  the only solution is to use the CVS stuff
I used dpkg -i --ignore-depends
I'm assuming apt/dpkg doesn't know about the stuff you compiled
it doesn't, no...
that's why I mentioned checkinstall
I'll take a look, thanks
'checkinstall' was exactly what I needed.  thank you for your help!
on the dev list they say the migration will be after dapper IIRC
launchpad for universe , currently bugzilla for main
heh - like the peanut packet that says 'Warning: this food may contain peanuts!' :D
xcdroast is old, but works well
you entered a bug about apt-cache failing, network issues etc, right ?
I raised hundreds of bugs :)
what about it?
I think I found a partial clue/ solution - if you disable daily checking in synaptic, it seems the apt-cache thing stops breaking
I confirmed your bug... hmm let me get the number
the problem seems to be that if your network connection is down or the repo is unavailable, apt-get will delete its cache of the repo contents instead of leaving it alone.
right
so by disabling the daily update in synaptic, users not always connected can work around the bug: but there should be some kind of check
I assume that's the synaptic setting that says 'update daily' or something
I don't know - I never run synaptic, and the update manager thingy is a separate program isn't it?
dunno - but as I said earlier, that setting seems to disable the check/update here
it appears to run with cron daily here
I noticed the bug surfaced after cron daily (the deletion thing)
the problem with cron is that I might not be booted into dapper at the time the crontab is scheduled to run.  then I'd miss the update
I think the 'cron daily' jobs are really run by anacron, not cron
right I see - but evidently anacron runs it as soon as you boot anyway
ah, you just said the same thing :)
I believe anacron runs the daily jobs at 7:30 each morning, or just after the first time you switch runlevels in a day, which ever comes first
yes, at about 7:35 here
but linux is a noun applied to the kernel
is there any good reason to use ubuntu's 2.6.12 kernel rather than a vanilla 2.6.14 kernel?
no idea , sorry - i would assume the ubuntu version is pretty heavily patched ?
I think that's the point - with 'knockd' they don't...
the octal permissions are based on the binary ones
really? no checkinstall in dapper? or a bug?
a bug I think
hope it gets fixed then - useful utility
interesting - ubotu couldn't find it
dpkg -S worked here ...
I used apt-file search
fair enough
I've only seen sudo cause problems with KDE apps, personally

you may be right - this was last year IIRC

k3b used to cause problems
right
no
did you seen ubotu's factoid:
yes, it has a typo
